case_name: Bansilal Abirchand Kasturchand v. Income-tax authorities

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 149 of 1956

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 149 of 1956. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated December 22, 1954, of the former Nagpur High Court in Misc. Civil Case No. 36 of 1954.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and order dated December 22, 1954 of Nagpur High Court in Misc. Civil Case No. 36 of 1954

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated December 22, 1954, of the former Nagpur High Court in Misc. Civil Case No. 36 of 1954. J. Kolah, J. M. Thakar, Ramesh A. Shroff, J. B. Dadachanji, S. N. Andley and Rameshwar Nath, for the appellant.

facts.text: Judgment of the Court delivered on April 25, 1958 by VENKATARAMA AIYAR J.

anchor.surface_text: 1958. April 25. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by VENKATARAMA AIYAR J.-This is an appeal against the judgment of the High Court of Nagpur in a reference under s. 66 1  of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922, hereinafter referred to as the Act.

facts.text: Appellant is sole proprietor of firm Bansilal Abirchand Kasturchand carrying on business as money-lenders, dealers in shares and bullion and commission agents in Bombay, Calcutta and other places

anchor.surface_text: The appellant is the sole proprietor of a firm called Bansilal Abirchand Kasturchand, which carries on business as money-lenders, dealers in shares and bullion and companymission agents in Bombay, Calcutta and other places.

facts.text: Appellant is resident of Bikaner and manages business through agents

anchor.surface_text: He is a resident of Bikaner, and manages the business at the several places through agents. During the relevant period, the agent of the firm at Bombay was one Chandratan, who held a power-of-attorney dated May 13, 1944,

facts.text: Agent at Bombay was Chandratan holding power-of-attorney dated May 13, 1944 conferring large powers including authority to operate bank accounts

anchor.surface_text: During the relevant period, the agent of the firm at Bombay was one Chandratan, who held a power-of-attorney dated May 13, 1944, companyferring on him large powers of management including authority to operate on bank accounts.

facts.text: From November 15, 1944 to November 23, 1944, agent withdrew Rs. 2,30,636-4-0 from firm's bank account and applied to personal debts in speculative transactions

anchor.surface_text: During the period, November 15, 1944, to November 23,1944, the agent withdrew from the firms bank account sums aggregating to Rs. 2,30,636-4-0, and applied them in satisfaction of his personal debts incurred in speculative transactions.

facts.text: On November 25, 1944, cashier sent telegram to appellant informing of the misappropriation

anchor.surface_text: On November 25, 1944, the cashier of the firm sent a telegram to the appellant informing him of the true state of affairs.

facts.text: Appellant went to Bombay on December 3, 1944

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon, the appellant went to Bombay on December 3, 1944, and on the 4th, cancelled the power-of-attorney given to the agent,

facts.text: On December 4, 1944, appellant cancelled power-of-attorney to agent

anchor.surface_text: and on the 4th, cancelled the power-of-attorney given to the agent, and by numberice dated December 6, 1944, called upon him to pay the amounts withdrawn by him.

facts.text: On December 6, 1944, notice sent to agent to pay amounts withdrawn

anchor.surface_text: and by numberice dated December 6, 1944, called upon him to pay the amounts withdrawn by him. The agent replied on December 8, 1944, admitting the misappropriation of the amounts and pleading for mercy.

facts.text: On December 8, 1944, agent replied admitting misappropriation

anchor.surface_text: The agent replied on December 8, 1944, admitting the misappropriation of the amounts and pleading for mercy. On January 16,1945, the appellant filed a suit against him in the High Court of Bombay for recovery of Rs. 2,30,636-4-0

facts.text: On January 16, 1945, appellant filed suit in High Court of Bombay for Rs. 2,30,636-4-0, decreed on February 20, 1945

anchor.surface_text: On January 16,1945, the appellant filed a suit against him in the High Court of Bombay for recovery of Rs. 2,30,636-4-0 and that was decreed on February 20, 1945.

facts.text: Rs. 28,000 recovered from Chandratan and adjusted towards decree, balance Rs. 2,02,442-13-9 written off as irrecoverable

anchor.surface_text: A sum of Rs. 28,000 was recovered from Chandratan and adjusted towards the decree and the balance of Rs. 2,02,442-13-9 was written off at the end of the accounting year as irrecoverable.

facts.text: Dispute before Income-tax authorities whether Rs. 2,02,442-13-9 admissible deduction

anchor.surface_text: Before the Income-tax authorities, the dispute related to the question whether this amount of Rs. 2,02,442-13-9 was an admissible deduction.

facts.text: Tribunal found amount represented loss by misappropriation by agent Chandratan but not trading loss per Curtis v. J.G. Oldfield

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal found that the amount in question represented the loss sustained by the appellant owing to misappropriation by his agent, Chandratan, but held on the authority of the decision in Curtis v. J. G. Oldfield, Limited  1  that it was number a trading loss and therefore companyld number be allowed.

facts.text: Tribunal referred question to High Court Nagpur on application of appellant

anchor.surface_text: On the application of the appellant, the Tribunal referred the following question of law for the decision of the High Court, Nagpur Whether the said sum of Rs. 2,02,442-13-9 being part of the amount embezzled by the assessees Munim is allowable as a deduction under the Indian Income-

facts.text: Nagpur High Court held governed by Curtis case and answered against appellant

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judges held that the case was governed by the decision in Curtis v. J. G. Oldfield, Limited  1 , and answered the question against the appellant.

facts.text: Application under s.66A for certificate dismissed, then special leave under Art.136 obtained

anchor.surface_text: An application under s. 66 A  2  for a certificate was also dismissed and thereafter, the appellant applied for and-obtained leave to appeal to this Court under Art. 136, and that is how the appeal companyes before us.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds loss incidental to business and deductible under s.10(1)

anchor.surface_text: In the result, we are of opinion that the loss sustained by the appellant as a result of misappropiriation by Chandratan is one which is incidental to the carrying, on of his business, and that it should therefore deducted in companyputing the profits under s. 10 1  of the, Act.

facts.text: Chandratan was in charge of business with authority to operate bank accounts

anchor.surface_text: When once it is established that Chandratan was in charge of the business, that he had authority to operate on the bank accounts, and that he with- drew the moneys in the purported exercise of that authority,

facts.text: No evidence required that withdrawal was for making advance, action referable to agent character

anchor.surface_text: his action is referable to his character as agent, and any loss resulting from misappropriation of funds by him would be a loss incidental to the carrying on of the business.

facts.text: Power-of-attorney related only to business, not private affairs

anchor.surface_text: We are also number satisfied that, on its true companystruction,, the authority companyferred on the agent by the power-of.attorney extended to the personal affairs of the appellant.

facts.text: Income-tax authorities finding assumes misappropriated moneys were business funds

anchor.surface_text: No such question was raised before the Income-tax authorities, and their finding assumes that the moneys which were misappropriated were business funds.

The question whether moneys embezzled by an agent or employee are allowable as deduction in computing the profits of a business under s. 10 of the Act has come up for consideration frequently before the Indian courts, and the decisions have not been quite uniform.

anchor.surface_text: The question whether moneys embezzled by an agent or employee are allowable as deduction in computing the profits of a business under s. 10 of the Act has come up for consideration frequently before the Indian courts, and the decisions have not been quite uniform. Before discussing them, it is necessary that we should examine the principles that are in law applicable to the determination of the question.

The question whether moneys embezzled by an agent or employee are allowable as deduction in computing the profits of a business under s. 10 of the Act has come up for consideration frequently before the Indian courts, and the decisions have not been quite uniform.

If that is established, then the deduction must be allowed,

holdings.text: The deduction is not admissible under s. 10(2)(xi) of the Act as the loss from misappropriation does not constitute a bad debt since it does not arise out of a contract, express or implied.

anchor.surface_text: As regards the first ground, the authorities have consistently held that the deduction is not admissible under s. 10 2  xi  of the Act, and that, in our view, is correct. A debt arises out of a contract between the parties, express or implied, and when an agent misappropriates monies belonging to his employer in fraud of him and in breach of his obligations to him, it cannot be said that he owes those monies under any agreement.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Misappropriation is fraud and breach of obligation, not contractual; journal entries do not create contract; consistent with authorities.

holdings.text: The claim for deduction cannot be admitted under s. 10(2)(xv) as the moneys were withdrawn without authority and in fraud, not expended wholly and exclusively for business purposes.

anchor.surface_text: Nor can a claim for deduction be admitted under s. 10 2  xv , because moneys which are withdrawn by the employee out of the business till without authority and in fraud of the proprietor can in no sense be said to be an expenditure laid out or expended wholly and exclusively for the purpose of the business.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Withdrawal in fraud not business expenditure per statutory requirement.

holdings.text: Section 10(2) enumerations are not exhaustive of all allowable deductions in computing profits under s. 10(1).

anchor.surface_text: Section 10 2  enumerates various items which are admissible as deductions, but it is well settled that they are not exhaustive of all allowances which could be made in ascertaining profits taxable under s. 10 1 .

holdings.reasoning_summary: Well-settled law; permits other deductions per commercial practice.

holdings.text: Profits and gains under s. 10(1) are to be computed according to ordinary commercial principles, including incidental losses.

anchor.surface_text: It is likewise well settled that profits and gains which are liable to be taxed under s. 10 1  are what are understood to be such according to ordinary commercial principles. The word profits is to be understood, observed Lord Halsbury in Gresham Life Assurance Society v. Styles  2 , in its natural and proper sense-in a sense which no commercial man would misunderstand.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cited English and Indian precedents; true profits require accounting for all losses per commercial practice.

holdings.text: A deduction for loss not specifically provided in s. 10(2) is admissible if it arises out of carrying on the business and is incidental to it per accepted commercial practice.

anchor.surface_text: The result is that when a claim is made for a deduction for which there is no specific provision in s. 10 2 , whether it is admissible or not will depend on whether, having regard to accepted commercial practice and trading principles, it can be said to arise out of the carrying on of the business and to be incidental to it.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Governing test derived from precedents like Chitnavis.

holdings.text: Loss from misappropriation by employee or agent is incidental to business as employment of staff is necessary for carrying on business.

anchor.surface_text: If employment of agents is incidental to the carrying on of business, it must logically follow that losses which are incidental to such employment are also incidental to the carrying on of the business. Human nature being what it is, it is impossible to rule out the possibility of an employee taking advantage of his position as such employee and misappropriating the funds of his employer, and the loss arising from such misappropriation must be held to arise out of the carrying on of business and to be incidental to it.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Logical from necessity of agents; per commercial view; human nature risk.

holdings.text: Loss from theft by stranger (e.g., breaking into premises) is not incidental to business, unlike employee embezzlement.

anchor.surface_text: At the same time, it should be emphasised that the loss for which a deduction could be made under s. 10 1  must be one that springs directly from the carrying on of the business and is incidental to it and not any loss sustained by the assessee, even if it has some connection with his business.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Fine distinction: business loss vs property owner loss; analogy to thief.

holdings.text: Curtis v. J.G. Oldfield is distinguishable and not applicable to money-lending/banking business where bank operations are continuous part of trade.

anchor.surface_text: Now, in Curtis v. J. G. Oldfield Limited 1 , the company was doing business in wine and spirit, and in such a business it is possible to hold that when once the price is realised and put into the bank, the trading has ceased and that the subsequent operations on the bank account are not incidental to the carrying on of the trade.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Fact-specific: wine trade vs banking; managing director like partner, not agent; no broad rule against post-collection embezzlement.

holdings.text: Once agent has authority to operate bank and withdraws in purported exercise thereof, action referable to agency; no need to prove specific business purpose like making advance.

anchor.surface_text: When once it is established that Chandratan was in charge of the business, that he had authority to operate on the bank accounts, and that he withdrew the moneys in the purported exercise of that authority, his action is referable to his character as agent, and any loss resulting from misappropriation of funds by him would be a loss incidental to the carrying on of the business.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Presumption from authority and purported exercise; applies to facts.

holdings.text: On true construction, power-of-attorney conferred authority only for business, not personal affairs; misappropriated funds were business funds.

anchor.surface_text: We are also not satisfied that, on its true construction, the authority conferred on the agent by the power-of-attorney extended to the personal affairs of the appellant. No such question was raised before the Income-tax authorities, and their finding assumes that the moneys which were misappropriated were business funds.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual construction; IT authorities' assumption; not raised below.

holdings.text: The loss of Rs. 2,02,442-13-9 is incidental to business and deductible under s.10(1); High Court answer reversed.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, we are of opinion that the loss sustained by the appellant as a result of misappropiriation by Chandratan is one which is incidental to the carrying, on of his business, and that it should therefore deducted in computing the profits under s. 10 1  of the, Act. In this view, the order of the lower court must be set aside and the reference answered in the affirmative.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies principles to facts: money-lending, agent authority, commercial practice; agrees with Venkatachalapathy etc.

anchor.surface_text: As regards the first ground, the authorities have consistently held that the deduction is not admissible under s. 10 2  xi  of the Act, and that, in our view, is correct. A debt arises out of a contract between the parties, express or implied, and when an agent misappropriates monies belonging to his employer in fraud of him and in breach of his obligations to him, it cannot be said that he owes those monies under any agreement.
In this view, the order of the lower companyrt must be set aside and the reference answered in the, affirmative.
In this view, the order of the lower companyrt must be set aside and the reference answered in the, affirmative.

The holding directly determines that the loss of Rs. 2,02,442-13-9 is incidental to business and deductible under s.10(1), reversing the High Court, thereby addressing the core issue of deductibility of the embezzled amount.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, we are of opinion that the loss sustained by the appellant as a result of misappropiriation by Chandratan is one which is incidental to the carrying, on of his business, and that it should therefore deducted in computing the profits under s. 10 1  of the, Act. In this view, the order of the lower court must be set aside and the reference answered in the affirmative.
In this view, the order of the lower companyrt must be set aside and the reference answered in the, affirmative.

Nor can a claim for deduction be admitted under s. 10 2  xv , because moneys which are withdrawn by the employee out of the business till without authority and in fraud of the proprietor can in no sense be said to be an expenditure laid out or expended wholly and exclusively for the purpose of the business.
In this view, the order of the lower companyrt must be set aside and the reference answered in the, affirmative.

anchor.surface_text: It is likewise well settled that profits and gains which are liable to be taxed under s. 10 1  are what are understood to be such according to ordinary commercial principles. The word profits is to be understood, observed Lord Halsbury in Gresham Life Assurance Society v. Styles  2 , in its natural and proper sense-in a sense which no commercial man would misunderstand.
In this view, the order of the lower companyrt must be set aside and the reference answered in the, affirmative.

anchor.surface_text: If employment of agents is incidental to the carrying on of business, it must logically follow that losses which are incidental to such employment are also incidental to the carrying on of the business. Human nature being what it is, it is impossible to rule out the possibility of an employee taking advantage of his position as such employee and misappropriating the funds of his employer, and the loss arising from such misappropriation must be held to arise out of the carrying on of business and to be incidental to it.

anchor.surface_text: Now, in Curtis v. J. G. Oldfield Limited 1 , the company was doing business in wine and spirit, and in such a business it is possible to hold that when once the price is realised and put into the bank, the trading has ceased and that the subsequent operations on the bank account are not incidental to the carrying on of the trade.
In this view, the order of the lower companyrt must be set aside and the reference answered in the, affirmative.
